title: Tiny beetle named after climate activist Greta Thunberg
text:
A newly identified species of beetle has been named after the environmental activist, Greta Thunberg by experts at London’s Natural History Museum.

Nelloptodes gretae, which is less than 1mm long and has no eyes or wings, belongs to the Ptiliidae family of beetles which includes some of the smallest insects in the world.

The beetle was first collected in samples of soil and leaf litter from Nairobi, Kenya by insect enthusiast Dr William Block in the 1960s, and his collection was donated to the Natural History Museum, London in 1978.

The creature was recently found by Dr Michael Darby whilst studying in the museum’s Spirit Collection, which houses over 22 million specimens.

Dr Darby, a Scientific Associate at the Natural History Museum, who has named the beetle, said he picked Thunberg for her work highlighting environmental concerns and the plight of wildlife.

“I chose this name as I am immensely impressed with the work of this young campaigner and wanted to acknowledge her outstanding contribution in raising awareness of environmental issues,” he said.
